antiPatterns.name: API Versioning
antiPatterns.description: A lack of semantically consistent versions of APIs (e.g. v1.1, v1.2, etc.).
antiPatterns.consequences: In case of updates to non-semantically versioned APIs, consumers may face breaking changes. For example, returned data may be different or may need to be called differently.
antiPatterns.solution: APIs need to be semantically versioned to allow services to know whether they are communicating with the correct version or whether they need to adapt their communication to a new contract.
antiPatterns.example: API release v1, then release v3
sources: @article{taibi2018definition, title={On the Definition of Microservice Bad Smells}, author={Taibi, Davide and Lenarduzzi, Valentina}, journal={IEEE software}, volume={35}, number={3}, pages={56--62}, year={2018}, publisher={IEEE}, doi={10.1109/ms.2018.2141031}}
